data.name: A Tome of Battle
entries: A common complaint about recent D&D is the gulf of power and utility that opens up between the warrior and the mage. While the wizard, cleric, and druid learn world-altering spells, the fighter swings his sword a few more times. Moreover, the metanalysis of weapon combat is largely solved, to the detriment of most of the weapon list. The tools in this document attempt to provide warriors with meaningful choices, options, and incentives to take actions other than 'I attack with the weapon I chose at level 1.'

This is primarily a 'gamist' document, so while flavor is considered, it does not claim to fix combat to some imagined realistic or historical standard, or expand the weapon list for its own sake. This work attempts to adhere to 5E conventions: only as few modifiers and rolls as necessary to the mechanics. Each set of rules is presented ala carte, so a DM may wish to allow only some of these pages or powers; a checklist is provided separately for that purpose

entries.name: Weapons and Techniques
entries: The vanilla weapon list has duplication and weapons with no mechanical value. The revised weapons table attempts to make any weapon an interesting choice for a warrior, balanced by weapon damage dice, properties, and available weapon techniques. These weapon techniques improve weaker weapons, take advantage of circumstances, or impose effects rather than increasing the damage ceiling.

entries.name: Combat Actions
entries: Actions beyond basic {@action attack|PHB|attacks} and {@action grapple|PHB|grapples} are often locked behind feats, making builds inflexible and competing with ability score improvements. The Combat Actions section moots certain feats (such as {@feat Charger} and {@feat Grappler}) with situational actions, codifies DMG object damage guidelines for combat, and adds more ways for PCs to interact with their enemies and environment.

entries.name: Stances
entries: An innovation in the 3E Tome of Battle, stances provide martial characters with passive bonuses during combat. Combat Stances replace 5E's Fighting Style feature with dynamic stances inspired by Unearthed Arcana and the Book of Nine Swords. Instead of one choice near character creation, a PC makes strategic and tactical choices during level-ups and rounds of combat.

entries.name: Maneuvers
entries: The final section vastly expands maneuvers, with specializations - Cut-Throat, Mystic Knight, Savage, or Warlord - that represent approaches to battlefield superiority alongside a standard maneuver group. Like warlock invocations, some maneuvers have level requirements and are correspondingly more powerful. These rules also include optional features to gain limited access to these powers in exchange for their lesser class bonuses: a fighter, paladin or ranger can replace a stance, a rogue can sacrifice some sneak attack damage to add on-hit effects, and a barbarian can reduce his critical damage bonus. At higher levels, monks learn to perform maneuvers using martial arts and ki.

rows: {@i Bandoleer}, {@i covert}, finesse, light, thrown (20/60), {@i reserve}
{@i Brutal, finesse, light, monk, reserve, special}

entries.name: Bandoleer
entries: You can draw this weapon from an appropriate container or case as part of making a thrown weapon attack with it.

entries.name: Brutal
entries: On a critical hit, this weapon adds 1d4 to the damage roll in addition to doubling the damage dice.

entries.name: Bladed
entries: The damage type of this weapon is piercing or slashing (your choice).

entries.name: Covert
entries: When you make a {@classFeature sneak attack|Rogue||1} with this weapon, your sneak attack dice become d8s instead of d6s. If you are hidden, a missed ranged attack does not reveal your location.

entries.name: Entrapping
entries: When you want to catch and restrain a weapon in combat, you can use the {@action Attack} action to make a special melee attack, an entrapment attempt with this weapon. If you have multiple attacks as part of the {@action Attack} action, this replaces one of them. The target of your entrapment must be within the reach of your weapon and wielding a melee or ranged weapon.

Make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check contested by the target's Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) (its choice). A creature wielding a weapon in two hands has advantage on this check, and a creature larger than you automatically wins. If you win, the target can't make attacks with the entrapped weapon until the entrapment ends.

You can't move out of your weapon's range, make an attack with the entrapping weapon, or drop your own weapon without releasing the entrapped weapon, which you can do at any time. If the target moves or is moved outside your weapon's reach, the entrapment ends and you can use your reaction to attempt to {@action Disarm|marpro} it (pg. 5) with advantage on your attack roll to do so.

entries.name: Escaping an Entrapment
entries: A creature can use its action to attempt to free its entrapped weapon by making a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check contested by your Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}).

entries.name: Heavy
entries: A heavy weapon's size or mass make it difficult to use without counterbalancing weight. Small and Tiny creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons as if using a weapon sized for a larger attacker {@book (DMG pg. 278)|DMG|9|Creating a Monster}. Small and Tiny creatures may craft versions of these weapons that are more suited to them, with the size of all damage dice reduced by 2 (e.g. 1d10 becomes 1d8, 2d6 becomes 2d4, etc.).

entries.name: Reserve
entries: Attacking with this weapon while {@condition prone} or {@condition restrained} does not impose disadvantage on the attack roll.

entries.name: Siege
entries: This weapon deals double damage to structures and objects.

data.name: Additional Combat Actions
entries: This section is intended to provide rules for characters to access conditions and effects that are otherwise only adjudicated by DM rulings, such as restraining a spellcaster or executing a prisoner. Some of these actions are intended to replace weaker combat feats or features, such as {@feat Charger}, {@feat Grappler}, or Berserker's {@subclassFeature Intimidating Presence|Barbarian||Berserker||10}. Others are alternatives to actions that become less attractive to martial characters with multiple attacks.

Some actions in this section utilize hit dice as a resource (marked with an asterisk), and a DM may want to disallow them; these powerful actions may grant excessive resources to a party that has fewer encounters and short rests per day.

data.name: Weapon Techniques
entries: When a class or feature grants you general proficiency with martial weapons, or you choose the {@classFeature Pact Boon|Warlock||3||Pact of the Blade}, {@subclassFeature Way of the Kensei|Monk||Kensei|XGE|3||Path of the Kensei}, or the {@subclassFeature Swashbuckler|Rogue||Swashbuckler|XGE|3} Archetype, you can choose to learn one technique that takes advantage of the properties of a weapon or family of weapons, as given on the table below. You learn one additional weapon technique of your choice each time you gain an Ability Score Improvement, or for each you have previously received.
At your DM's discretion, you can learn a new technique by spending a number of downtime days equal to 10 minus your Intelligence modifier training with an appropriate expert.

When a technique requires a saving throw, the DC is 8 + your weapon attack bonus. A technique can only be used while wielding a weapon in its list, and you must use the technique with a weapon in its list, unless otherwise noted. When a technique deals damage to a creature, you can add any appropriate bonus from your weapon or class features to the damage roll, such as a barbarian's {@classFeature rage|Barbarian||1} bonus or a {@item flame tongue}'s fire damage, but not an effect that triggers on a hit, such as {@classFeature sneak attack|Rogue||1} or {@classFeature divine smite|Paladin||2}.

When a technique is used as a special melee attack, it must replace the attack granted by the {@action Attack} action. If you have multiple attacks as part of the {@action Attack} action, the technique replaces one of them.

data.name: Combat Stances
entries: Stances were originally presented in the Book of Nine Swords for Third Edition, granting certain classes powers that continually boost a warrior's abilities. Fifth Edition uses some of this concept in Fighting Styles, available to most martial classes, and this document replaces those features with the following:

entries.name: Combat Stance
entries: {@i Replaces Fighting Style}

You adopt a particular style of fighting with the flexibility to shift your stance, flowing seamlessly between offense and defense. Each time you gain this feature, you learn two stances of your choice from the below list. After this, each time you gain Extra Attack or an improvement to Extra Attack, you learn two more stances of your choice.
When you gain a level, you can replace one stance you know with another one, if you meet its requirements.

You can enter or change stance when you roll initiative, or as a bonus action on your turn, choosing from your stances known. You can maintain only one stance at a time, and you lose any stance bonus while incapacitated.

entries.name: Hybrid Stance
entries: {@i Replaces {@subclassFeature Additional Fighting Style|Fighter||Champion||10}}
At 10th level, you can enter and maintain two stances at the same time. In addition, you learn one stance of your choice.

entries.name: Feat: Fighting Initiate
entries: {@feat Fighting Initiate|marpro}

entries.name: Basic Stances
entries: The stances listed below have no prerequisites.

entries.name: Advanced Stances
entries: To learn or use one of these stances, you must meet the prerequisites listed. An advanced stance improves a basic stance, granting both its benefits and that of the basic stance that it references.

data.name: Maneuvers Expanded
entries: These combat maneuvers are intended to supplement the ones provided in the PHB for Battlemasters. The {@subclassFeature Battle Master|Fighter||Battle Master||3||Battlemaster} Archetype replaces the PHB Combat Superiority feature with the below feature. By taking {@optfeature Specialized Technique|marpro} (pg. 11) as an alternative to taking a Fighting Style or Combat Stance, Superior Technique grants a measure of Battlemaster prowess to any warrior.

entries.name: Combat Superiority (Revised)
entries: {@i Replaces {@subclassFeature Battle Master|Fighter||Battle Master||3||Combat Superiority}}

When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you learn maneuvers that are fueled by special dice called superiority dice. Choose a specialization - {@filter Cut-Throat|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM:C}, {@filter Mystic Knight|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM:M}, {@filter Savage|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM:S}, or {@filter Warlord|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM:W} - which you cannot change later, reflecting the style of your battlefield superiority.

{@b Maneuvers.} You learn four maneuvers of your choice, which are detailed below, that must be chosen from your specialization or the {@filter Combat Maneuvers|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM} group. If a maneuver has prerequisites, you must meet the requirements to choose or use it. Many maneuvers enhance an attack in some way; if so, you can use only one maneuver per attack. Other maneuvers replace an attack or action. If such a maneuver requires an attack roll, you can add any magical bonuses from your weapon to the damage roll.
You learn two additional maneuvers of your choice at 7th, 10th, and 15th level. At the end of a long rest, you can replace one maneuver you know with a different eligible one.

{@b Superiority Dice.} You have four superiority dice, which are {@dice d8}s. A superiority die is expended when you use it. You regain all of your expended superiority dice when you finish a short or long rest. You gain another superiority die at 7th and at 15th level.
{@b Saving Throws.} Some of your maneuvers require your target to make a saving throw to resist the maneuver's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:
{@b Maneuver save DC} = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice)

entries.name: Superior Technique
entries: {@i Replaces {@feat Martial Adept}}

Choose a specialization - {@filter Cut-Throat|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM:C}, {@filter Mystic Knight|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM:M}, {@filter Savage|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM:S}, or {@filter Warlord|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM:W} - if you do not have one already. You learn two maneuvers from your chosen specialization or the {@filter Combat Maneuvers|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM} group, following the rules above except as modified below.
You gain two superiority dice, which is a {@dice d4}s (these dice are added to any superiority dice you have from another source) and does not change size as you gain levels.

If you gain this feat or feature again, you learn two additional maneuvers from your specialization or the Combat Maneuvers group, and gain one maneuver die. Your superiority dice from this feature (but not from any other source) increase in size by 2 (e.g. from d4s to d6s), up to a maximum of d12s.

Unless you also have {@variantrule Maneuvers Expanded|marpro|Combat Superiority}, you cannot replace maneuvers gained from this feature at the end of a long rest. Instead, when you gain a level, you can replace one maneuver you know with a different eligible maneuver from your specialization or the Combat Maneuvers group.

entries.name: Ki-Fueled Superiority
entries: {@i Optional 7th-level monk feature }

Your focused training has resulted in secret, deadly techniques. You learn two maneuvers of your choice, but do not gain any superiority dice. When you use a maneuver gained from this feature, roll your martial arts die instead of a superiority die. You can't use stunning strike on an attack caused or affected by a maneuver.

You can use these maneuvers a number of times, combined, equal to your Wisdom modifier, and regain all uses when you finish a long rest. While you have no uses available, you can use a maneuver by spending 1 ki point. When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one maneuver granted by this feature with a different eligible one.

entries.name: Roguish Superiority
entries: {@i Optional 5th level rogue feature}

You learn {@filter two maneuvers of your choice, which must be triggered by your weapon attack hitting a creature|optionalfeatures|feature type=RS}. When you gain a level in this class, you can replace a maneuver you know from this feature with a different eligible one.

When you hit with an attack that is eligible for sneak attack on your turn, you can instead apply a maneuver you know to it. In place of a superiority die, roll your sneak attack dice, but remove the two highest rolls. This counts as a use of sneak attack.

entries.name: Raging Superiority
entries: {@i Alternative 9th, 13th, 17th level barbarian feature}

Your combat style is unrefined but effective. In place of {@classFeature Brutal Critical (1 die)|Barbarian||1||Brutal Critical}, you can choose to instead gain the {@variantrule Maneuvers Expanded|marpro|Superior Technique} feature.

entries.name: Combat Maneuvers
entries: An asterisk (*) denotes a modified PHB/TCE maneuver. A cross (+) denotes a maneuver eligible for {@filter Roguish Technique|optionalfeatures|feature type=RS}. {@note A PHB/TCE page denotes an unmodified PHB/TCE maneuver}

data.name: Frequently Asked Questions
entries: {@note This FAQ is in the 'Martial Prowess: A DM's Checklist' side file.}

entries.name: Why not just play Pathfinder 2?
entries: Send me a game invite. Seriously, PF2E is fantastic and well-balanced, but it's significantly easier to find a game of 5E, even modified. My intention with this supplement is to make the additions and changes as seamless and elegant as possible, while maintaining general compatibility with standard 5E conventions and classes.

entries.name: What are the Maneuver subsections?
entries: They're maneuver specializations, like schools of magic or a cleric vs wizard spell list. Since I've added over 40 additional maneuvers, I recommend that each martial who gets maneuver dice choose one (and only one) specialization, plus the general {@filter Combat Maneuvers|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM} group. That reduces the total number of choices from more than 70 to about 30, which is intended to avoid choice paralysis and keep the new stuff from overwhelming a player - instead of six pages to thumb through, about three.

The {@filter Warlord|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM:W} has most of the original Battlemaster maneuvers, if one wanted to pick the most 'vanilla' of the choices. The {@filter Mystic Knight|optionalfeatures|feature type=CM:M} is probably the most out-there specialization, with pseudo-magical effects like a Tome of Battle Swordsage.

entries.name: Do you need to know both the Advanced and Basic stance to use an Advanced stance?
entries: Yes. An {@filter Advanced stance|optionalfeatures|feature type=CS:A} modifies a basic stance, so you need to make two stance selections to use any Advanced stance.

entries.name: How do the revised Fighting Style and Maneuver feats work together?
entries: Intentionally. If you are using both systems, it is NOT recommended to take {@feat Fighting Initiate|TCE} as a feat, because {@feat Fighting Initiate|marpro} (Revised) grants proficiencies and a Stance, which can be used to take {@optfeature Specialized Technique|marpro}.

entries.name: What stances do Swords Bards, etc get access to?
entries: {@filter Any that don't have a prerequisite such as Fighter Only|optionalfeatures|feature type=CS:G}.

entries.name: Can Techniques be used together, on the same turn or attack?
entries: Yes.

entries.name: Can I Thrash multiple squares with Extra Attack?
entries: Hell yes.

entries.name: Can I smite, sneak attack, etc. off Shattering Clobber, Thrash, or Cleave?
entries: No. If an effect is triggered by an attack roll, Techniques that use saving throws do not trigger it.

entries.name: Does Cleave's die change interact with Fencing's die increase?
entries: Yes. The d4 damage die becomes a d6.

entries.name: Can I smite/sneak attack with Savagery?
entries: {@optfeature Savagery (Raging Demon)|marpro|Savagery} affects weapon dice, not damage dice, so no on sneak attack or smite. Savagery does affect the damage dice of saving throw-based techniques.

entries.name: Why do Rogues, Barbarians, and Monks get access to maneuvers later?
entries: Mostly because they're in a pretty decent spot before tier 2. Barbarians have a strong class identity that doesn't involve 'technique' (and are mechanically strong). Their class identity isn't primarily about combat maneuvers, so they trade some class features for those maneuvers.

Rogues get an extra ASI at level 10, so they can already get Superior Technique (if they want it). But in 4E, rogues were the kings of status effects, with at-wills that did good damage AND made the battlefield interesting. Roguish Technique is designed to reduce their damage noticeably in order to give at-will access to maneuvers.

Monks have good to great damage and control through tier 2, then begin to fall off compared to other martials. They are multi-attribute dependent, so cannot budget extra ASIs on feats. By granting Ki-Fueled Technique at level 7, it grows with their wisdom ASI and martial arts die.

entries.name: What feats or features are depreciated by this?
entries: {@feat Weapon Master}, {@feat Grappler}, and {@feat Charger}. {@feat Skulker} somewhat (covert weapons).

entries.name: Why use pre-Tashas names and features?
entries: I like them better, and they don't infringe on WOTC's copyright as badly :)

entries.name: What are some tweaks and minor buffs that I might have missed?
entries: Some important class and subclass features:

items: Monks can use the {@item cestus|marpro} and {@item saber|marpro}.

Rogues can make good use of the {@i covert} property on {@item dagger|marpro|daggers} and {@item blowgun|marpro|blowguns}, dealing better damage than with {@item rapier|marpro|rapiers}/{@item shortbow|marpro|shortbows} as their sneak attack dice increase in number.
{@subclassFeature Path of the Berserker|Barbarian||Berserker||3||Berserker} Barbarian can use its L10 ({@subclassFeature Intimidating Presence|Barbarian||Berserker||10||Terrorize}) as a bonus action.

{@subclassFeature Way of the Kensei|Monk||Kensei|XGE|3||Kensei}, {@subclassFeature Swashbuckler|Rogue||Swashbuckler|XGE|3}, and {@classFeature Pact Boon|Warlock||3||Blade Pact} subclasses get weapon techniques. {@optfeature Flexible Flurry|marpro} works especially well with Kensei.
{@subclassFeature Champion|Fighter||Champion||3} can use {@subclassFeature Additional Fighting Style|Fighter||Champion||10||two stances}, even two advanced stances, at the same time.
{@optfeature Dueling (Desert Wind)|marpro|Dueling} stance can be used with a versatile or two-handed weapon.

entries.name: Are there any other rules changes you use with this?
entries: Quite a few! I use a hybrid sorcerer (spellpoints for 1st-5th level spells, slots for 6th+) and make a few changes to various subclass features, in addition to my collection of homebrew subclasses.

On the DM side, I recommend preponderance of advantage (2 instances of adv vs 1 disadv = adv), +5/-5 vulnerability/resistance in the 4E style, and use of action-oriented/Big Bad Solo Inserts/Paragon monsters to challenge my players in interesting ways.

entries.name: Converter's notes about FoundryVTT
entries: {@note This is not part of the actual FAQ}

The plutonium import for Techniques and Maneuvers assume that Strength is the ability used for damage and saving throw scaling for most actions, change it to dexterity if you are using a finesse or ranged weapon. Maneuvers also assume a 1d8 superiority die. You'll need to manually add any damage and DC bonus, like when using +1 weapons, to the feature. Since we cannot add modifiers to save DC, you'll have to set it to flat and add it manually.
Maneuvers by default will use the third resource in the character sheet as their Superiority Dice pool.

5etools and Plutonium Import do not like features and items sharing the same name. In 5etools it will mess the generic variants automation (like +1 weapon) for homebrew weapons, this can be fixed by blacklisting in PHB weapons. Plutonium will hide this brew's weapons in the importer if 5etools is checked while importing, unchecking 5etools will not prevent generic variants from applying to this brew's weapons.

Since this brew add several weapon properties, in order to see them on the weapon, make sure that 'Include Damage, Properties, Rarity and Attunement in Description' is checked in Plutonium Import (Items) settings. Consider checking 'Collapse Item Cards in Chat' in system settings to keep the chat log clear of massive descriptive texts.

If a maneuver has prerequisites, you must meet the requirements to choose or use it.
You gain two superiority dice, which is a {@dice d4}s (these dice are added to any superiority dice you have from another source) and does not change size as you gain levels.

If you gain this feat or feature again, you learn two additional maneuvers from your specialization or the Combat Maneuvers group, and gain one maneuver die. Your superiority dice from this feature (but not from any other source) increase in size by 2 (e.g. from d4s to d6s), up to a maximum of d12s.

Unless you also have {@variantrule Maneuvers Expanded|marpro|Combat Superiority}, you cannot replace maneuvers gained from this feature at the end of a long rest. Instead, when you gain a level, you can replace one maneuver you know with a different eligible maneuver from your specialization or the Combat Maneuvers group.

entries.name: Ki-Fueled Superiority
entries: {@i Optional 7th-level monk feature }

Your focused training has resulted in secret, deadly techniques. You learn two maneuvers of your choice, but do not gain any superiority dice. When you use a maneuver gained from this feature, roll your martial arts die instead of a superiority die. You can't use stunning strike on an attack caused or affected by a maneuver.

You can use these maneuvers a number of times, combined, equal to your Wisdom modifier, and regain all uses when you finish a long rest. While you have no uses available, you can use a maneuver by spending 1 ki point. When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one maneuver granted by this feature with a different eligible one.

entries.name: Roguish Superiority
entries: {@i Optional 5th level rogue feature}

You learn {@filter two maneuvers of your choice, which must be triggered by your weapon attack hitting a creature|optionalfeatures|feature type=RS}. When you gain a level in this class, you can replace a maneuver you know from this feature with a different eligible one.

When you hit with an attack that is eligible for sneak attack on your turn, you can instead apply a maneuver you know to it. In place of a superiority die, roll your sneak attack dice, but remove the two highest rolls. This counts as a use of sneak attack.

entries.name: Raging Superiority
entries: {@i Alternative 9th, 13th, 17th level barbarian feature}

Your combat style is unrefined but effective. In place of {@classFeature Brutal Critical (1 die)|Barbarian||1||Brutal Critical}, you can choose to instead gain the {@variantrule Maneuvers Expanded|marpro|Superior Technique} feature.

entries.name: Brutal
entries: On a critical hit, this weapon adds {@damage 1d4} to the damage roll in addition to doubling the damage dice.

entries.name: Bandoleer
entries: You can draw this weapon from an appropriate container or case as part of making a thrown weapon attack with it.

entries.name: Bladed
entries: The damage type of this weapon is piercing or slashing (your choice).

entries.name: Covert
entries: When you make a sneak attack with this weapon, your sneak attack dice become d8s instead of d6s. If you are hidden, a missed ranged attack does not reveal your location.

entries.name: Entrapping
entries: When you want to catch and restrain a weapon in combat, you can use the {@action Attack} action to make a special melee attack, an entrapment attempt with this weapon. If you have multiple attacks as part of the {@action Attack} action, this replaces one of them. The target of your entrapment must be within the reach of your weapon and wielding a melee or ranged weapon.

Make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check contested by the target's Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) (its choice). A creature wielding a weapon in two hands has advantage on this check, and a creature larger than you automatically wins. If you win, the target can't make attacks with the entrapped weapon until the entrapment ends.

You can't move out of your weapon's range, make an attack with the entrapping weapon, or drop your own weapon without releasing the entrapped weapon, which you can do at any time. If the target moves or is moved outside your weapon's reach, the entrapment ends and you can use your reaction to attempt to {@action Disarm|marpro} it (pg. 5) with advantage on your attack roll to do so.

entries.name: Heavy
entries: A heavy weapon's size or mass make it difficult to use without counterbalancing weight. Small and Tiny creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons as if using a weapon sized for a larger attacker {@book (DMG pg. 278)|DMG|9|Creating a Monster}. Small and Tiny creatures may craft versions of these weapons that are more suited to them, with the size of all damage dice reduced by 2 (e.g. 1d10 becomes 1d8, 2d6 becomes 2d4, etc.).

entries.name: Reserve
entries: Attacking with this weapon while {@condition prone} or {@condition restrained} does not impose disadvantage on the attack roll.

entries.name: Siege
entries: This weapon deals double damage to structures and objects.

baseitem.name: Cestus
entries: The cestus, or brass knuckles, are any striking glove or weapon that protects the hand while adding power to strikes. Claw weapons may deal slashing or piercing damage instead. Add the cestus to the monk weapons list {@book (PHB pg.78)|PHB|3}.

entries.name: Special
entries: Your attacks with this weapon are also considered to be unarmed strikes.

entries.name: Special
entries: You have disadvantage when you use a lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a lance requires two hands to wield when you aren't mounted.

baseitem.name: Saber
entries: A curved, single-edged sword often used as a sidearm. Add the saber to the monk weapons list {@book (PHB pg.78)|PHB|3}.

baseitem.name: Swordbreaker
entries: A dagger with a series of hooked, horizontal notches opposite the blade, used to catch and entrap the opponent's weapon.

baseitem.name: War Whip
entries: A reinforced whip, juijieban, kusarigama, meteor hammer, or other martial variant of the whip.

baseitem.name: Greatbow
entries: A greatbow is a massive arc of sturdy wood, much larger than a typical longbow, with draw weight beyond the strength of most men. It cannot be used while mounted, and readying or stowing it uses your bonus action or action, instead of an object interaction. Creatures with less than 15 Strength make attacks with the greatbow with disadvantage, while creatures with less than 11 strength cannot draw it at all.

entries.name: Special
entries: You add your Strength modifier instead of your Dexterity modifier to your greatbow damage roll.

entries.name: Special
entries: A Large or smaller creature hit by a net is {@condition restrained} until it is freed. A net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to make a DC 10 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net. When you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to attack with a net, you can make only one attack regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

action.name: Castle
entries: As an action, you can move into the space of a willing creature within 5 feet of you, moving the creature into the space you previously occupied. You must both fit in the space available. Neither you nor the target provoke opportunity attacks for this movement.

action.name: Charge
entries: You can use your momentum to enhance your rushing attack. When you (or your mount) uses an action to {@action Dash} and you move at least 10 feet in a straight line towards a creature, you can make one melee attack against it as a bonus action. If you hit, you can choose to push the creature 5 feet away from you. Hit or miss, your speed becomes 0 until the end of your turn.

action.name: Disarm
entries: DMG pg. 271 ({@action Disarm|dmg}) revised

As an action, or in place of two weapon {@action attack|PHB|attacks}, you attempt to knock a weapon or another item from a target's grasp by making an attack roll contested by the target's Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check (its choice). If you win, the attack causes no damage or other ill effect, but the defender drops the item, which lands in an unoccupied space of your choice within 15 feet of it. Items that are worn or attached cannot be disarmed.

You have disadvantage on your attack roll if the target is holding the item with two or more hands. The target has advantage on its ability check if it is larger than you, or disadvantage if it is smaller.

action.name: Distraction
entries: When you take the {@action Attack} action, you can replace one of your weapon attacks with a move that puts an enemy off-balance. Make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check against the Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check of a creature within 5 feet of you. If you win this check, the creature cannot take reactions until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Flee
entries: When you {@action Dash} as an action and are not within a hostile creature's reach, you can attempt to flee the battlefield, dropping any items in your hands. If you do so, you can move half your speed as a bonus action, so long as your movement is in the safest possible route away from all threats. If a creature uses both its movement and action to {@action Dash} in pursuit of you, it cannot use the {@action Charge|marpro} action and the DM may begin a Chase {@book (DMG pg. 252)|DMG|8|Chases} if appropriate.

action.name: Overrun / Tumble
entries: DMG pg. 272 ({@action Overrun|dmg} / {@action Tumble|dmg}) revised

When you try to move through a hostile creature's space, you can try to force through by overrunning the creature. As an action or bonus action, make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check contested by the creature's Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. You have advantage on your roll if you are larger than the creature, or disadvantage if you are smaller. If you win, you can move through (but not end your turn in) the hostile creature's space once on this turn.

Alternatively, you can attempt to duck, dodge, and weave past the hostile creature. As an action or bonus action, make a Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check contested by the creature's Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. If you win, you can move through (but not end your turn in) the hostile creature's space once this turn. If the creature wins, it can use its reaction to attempt to {@action shove} you {@condition prone}.

action.name: Seize
entries: While grappling a target that is your size or smaller, you can attempt to pin it with an additional free hand. As a special melee attack, make another {@action grapple} check. If you win, both you and the target are {@condition restrained} until the grapple ends, and you can choose one of the following additional effects:

items: You maneuver to the target's side or back. While {@condition restrained}, the creature cannot attack you.
You pin the target's hands and arms. While {@condition restrained}, the creature cannot cast a spell with a somatic component, draw a non-light weapon, or take the {@action Use an Object} action.

You cover the target's mouth and muffle its speech. While {@condition restrained}, the creature cannot be heard clearly beyond 15 feet, or at all beyond 30 feet. If the creature attempts to cast a spell with a verbal component, it must make a Dexterity saving throw against a DC of 8 + your Strength modifier. On a failed saving throw, the spell fails but the spell slot is not lost.

entries: A creature can be subject to only one of these effects from each creature grappling it.

action.name: Sunder
entries: {@book (DMG pg. 246)|DMG|8|Objects}, extended

As an action, or in place of two weapon {@action attack|PHB|attacks}, you can attempt to break a weapon, shield, armor, or object the target is wearing or holding. The attack roll is made against the object's AC, plus the Dexterity modifier and any circumstantial or magical bonuses to AC of the creature holding or wearing it. The object has three-quarters cover if it is not being held, and you have disadvantage on the attack roll if the object is more than one size smaller than the target.

On a hit, you deal damage to the object. If the object is reduced to 0 hit points, it is broken and can't be used in a normal fashion until it is repaired. The AC of sundered armor is reduced by 2 instead. An item can be repaired via magic or by spending 1 hour using an appropriate set of tools, possibly requiring part of the item's value in raw materials.

The hit points and AC of an object are subject to your DM's discretion, with some guidelines provided here and in the DMG. Most creatures wield weapons and shields that are small, resilient objects with 11 ({@dice 3d6}) hit points, while most medium-sized armor has 5 ({@dice 1d8}) hit points for each point of AC above 10. Most leather or wood objects have 15 AC and iron or steel objects have 19 AC. Most adventuring equipment has resistance to nonmagical damage and immunity to psychic and poison damage. Magical weapons or objects may be immune to sundering damage.

action.name: Tackle
entries: You charge an opponent, attempting to subdue it using your momentum and weight. When you use your action to {@action Dash} and you move at least 10 feet in a straight line towards a creature, you can attempt to {@action grapple} or {@action shove} it as a bonus action. If you win the opposed check, the target is knocked {@condition prone} and either {@condition grappled} or pushed 5 feet (your choice). Otherwise, the target is unaffected.
In either case, you are knocked {@condition prone} and your speed becomes 0 until the end of your turn.

action.name: Coup de Grace
entries: As an action, you attempt to finish a helpless opponent, one that is {@condition unconscious}, {@condition paralyzed}, or otherwise rendered unable to take actions or use movement (the {@condition incapacitated} condition is necessary but not sufficient). You deal an automatic critical hit with a melee attack (no attack roll needed). If the creature survives the damage, it must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against a DC equal to 10 or half your damage roll, whichever is higher. On a failure, it dies. A rogue applies sneak attack damage when delivering a coup de grace.
Delivering a coup de grace provokes opportunity attacks from creatures within 5 feet of you and reduces your speed to 0 until the end of the turn.

action.name: First Aid
entries: As an action, you bind wounds and apply simple first aid with a {@item Healer's Kit|phb}. Expend a use of the kit and make a DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check targeting a creature within five feet of you that has less than half its maximum number of hit points. On a success, the target can choose to expend one hit die as if it did so during a short rest, plus one additional die for each 5 points you exceed the DC. If the creature's current hit points exceed half of its maximum hit points after expending a die, it cannot expend any more dice, even if your check result would allow it to do so.

action.name: Heroic Resolve
entries: When you make a death saving throw, you can expend and roll a hit die, adding the result to your roll. You must choose to do so before making the roll. If you roll a 1 on the {@dice d20} but the total result would succeed, the roll counts as one failure instead of two.
You gain a level of exhaustion, and recover one fewer hit die (minimum zero) at the end of your next long rest.

action.name: Knockout Blow
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a surprised or {@condition restrained} creature with a bludgeoning attack, you can try to knock it out. Roll your damage as normal, but instead of taking damage the creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against a DC equal to 10 or half your damage roll, whichever is higher, or it is rendered {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute. The target awakens if it takes damage or another creature uses an action to wake it. This ability has no effect on constructs and undead.

action.name: Hurl
entries: If you are grappling a target your size or smaller, you can exert yourself in an attempt to hit it with the ground. As a special melee attack, expend one or more hit dice, up to a number equal to your Strength modifier. You sling the creature 5 feet away from you and it must make a Dexterity saving throw against a DC equal to 8 + your Strength ({@skill Athletics}) modifier, or it is thrown an additional 5 feet per hit die expended and lands {@condition prone}.
The creature takes bludgeoning damage equal to your Strength modifier, plus {@damage 1d4} for each 5 feet it was thrown.

action.name: Sprint
entries: Pushing yourself to go slightly faster, you overexert yourself while moving into or out of danger. When you use your action or bonus action to Dash, you can expend a hit die and move just a bit farther, gaining an amount of speed equal to 5 x half the die roll (rounded up) until the end of your turn.
You cannot use this ability if your speed has been reduced by an effect or condition..

action.name: Terrorize
entries: You can use your action to frighten someone with your presence. Choose one creature within 15 feet of you that can see or hear you. It must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma or Strength modifier) or be {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn. On subsequent turns, you can use your action to extend the duration of this effect on the {@condition frightened} creature until the end of your next turn. This effect ends if the creature ends its turn out of line of sight or more than 60 feet away from you. If the creature succeeds on its saving throw or the {@condition frightened} condition ends, you can't use this feature on that creature again for 24 hours.
A 10th level barbarian who follows the {@subclassFeature Path of the Berserker|Barbarian||Berserker||3} can initiate or extend this ability as a bonus action.
